item.title: SvelteKit is my üçáJam!(Stack)
item.description: I guess you could say this is the üåíend of an era. I guess you could say this is the üåòbeginning of a new one.
item.content:encoded:
I guess you could say this is the üåíend of an era. I guess you could say this is the üåòbeginning of a new one. What can I say? I had multiple versions of the same website, and now, I only have just one, and you barge in here, into my blog, demanding that I explain myself? Well, you have some guts.

I have discovered that I am quite a fan of the Svelte way of doing things. In a lot of ways, it feels kind of like a natural extension of the üç¶vanilla web platform, and that is very much by üìêdesign.

svelte: ./src/components/media-gallery/media-gallery.svelte

      
<script lang='ts'>
  import type { IMedia } from '@marmadilemanteater/gh-static-site-lib/src/models/social-posts'
  // component props are just exported variables!? that's üëçneat
  export let medias: IMedia[] = []
  export let descriptionText: string = ''
  // ... omitted for brevity ...
  // computed values just use a prefix, üëÄ
  $: images = medias.filter(media => !media.url?.endsWith('mp4')).map(removeGhAssetsLinks)
  // but are otherwise easily readable statements !?!? üò≤
  $: videos = medias.filter(media => media.url?.endsWith('mp4')).map(removeGhAssetsLinks)
  // no `useEffect(() => {}, [store1, store2, etc])` or anything like that required ü§Ø
</script>
<div
  class="overflow-hidden media-grid grid max-w-full {images.length < 2?'flex flex-col justify-center bg-black': ''}"
>
  <!-- no janky iteration situations with `.map` !??!? -->
  <!-- because svelte has proper syntax for logic~!!!!ü§© -->
  {#each images as image, i}
    <!-- 
      proper if statements in templates
      without a `v-if` on an element 
      or the need for ternary operators !?!?!?ü•∞
    -->
    {#if image.url !== undefined}
      <!-- omitted for brevity -->
    {/if}
  {/each}
</div>
<!-- template code can go at the top level?? no <template> tag required!??!? üí• -->
<div
  class='overflow-hidden media-grid grid max-w-full flex flex-col justify-center bg-black'
>
  <!-- omitted for brevity -->
</div>

This component syntax does everything that I want it to do without me having to put a whole lot of üß†thought into it, and I just can't really say that for ‚öõReact-like JSX syntax or even Vue syntax. It just feels like what web development should be, out of the üì¶box, and what can I say? I just think it's ‚ú®neat.

Of course, that's only one piece of this üß©puzzle!

So far, I've only been talking about Svelte, the frontend framework, but what about Sveltekit? Even though I could technically be using üë©‚ÄçüöÄAstro to do the same thing (because I don't client side render), I personally prefer Sveltekit for the time being because I like it more than Astro's syntax which isn't JSX, but it is still JSX-like enough that I don't like it. My opinion on this could easily change, but it all comes down to whether or not I even want any ü•§hydration at all in the future.

STOP DOING CLIENT SIDE NAVIGATION

  • WEBSITES WERE NEVER SUPPOSED TO BE CLIENT SIDE RENDERED
  • YEARS OF RENDERING IN THE BROWSER AND YET STILL NO REAL WORLD USE FOUND FOR ANYTHING BEYOND HTML & CSS
  • Want client side navigation anyway, for a laugh? We had a tool for that: it was called "@hotwire/turbo"
  • "Event listeners need to be wrapped with a `$()` so that they can be split into lazy loaded chunks" - Statements dreamed up by the utterly Deranged

Look at what JAVASCRIPT FRAMEWORKS have been demanding your respect for:

(This is real CLIENT SIDE NAVIGATION, done by real JAVASCRIPT FRAMEWORKS)

Floating orb of nothingness

Page says 'loading', but is an error

????

THEY HAVE PLAYED US ALL FOR FOOLS!

There we go. I said it. Finally, I got to the point I was trying to make this whole time.

Why are you trying to reinvent browser navigation? Browsers already figured out how to do page navigation with good UX! They tell the user if the page is still loading. They might even give the user a little progress bar to let them know it is not just spinning forever.

That's it. That's all I had to say. I might go back to Astro with Svelte eventually to try out View Transitions which are based on the experimental View Transitions API. At the very least, it keeps the browser in charge of handling page navigation.

item.title: I ran into a problem today with re-parenting nodes within...
item.description:
I ran into a problem today with re-parenting nodes within an Area2D.body_entered signal. My game was just crashing abruptly when attempting to re-parent the player node during a scene change. Then, I found an issue on GH that looks similar to what I was experiencing: https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/34207 (even if this is technically 3d, not 2d ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è), and I discovered that I could fix my problem by deferring the re-parenting of the player node with a timer‚è≥.
#GodotEngine #AnotherDayAnotherProject

media:content.media:description: a 2d sprite of a person walking into and out of a building; when the person enters the building, the building is visible, and when the person is outside the building, only the outside is visible.

item.content:encoded:
I ran into a problem today with re-parenting nodes within an Area2D.body_entered signal. My game was just crashing abruptly when attempting to re-parent the player node during a scene change. Then, I found an issue on GH that looks similar to what I was experiencing: https://github.com/godotengine/godot/issues/34207 (even if this is technically 3d, not 2d ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è), and I discovered that I could fix my problem by deferring the re-parenting of the player node with a timer‚è≥.
#GodotEngine #AnotherDayAnotherProject

Since my submission, I worked to add üñ± mouse controls to my game in order to accommodate someone in my life, so if using a mouse is more comfortable for you than using a controller or keyboard, this is the post jam update for you~! item.title: It is neat that you can export variables from your...
item.description: It is neat that you can export variables from your scripts and toggle them in the Godot editor while the game is running to quickly see what changing the state would do at any given moment. It's something I haven't really played with too much before, but I find it useful now that I am dipping my toes in that üåäwater. #FediverseJam #GodotEngine

media:content.media:description: two windows side by side. On the left, the game window displays a menu with items that bob up and down when they are selected. On the right, the godot editor's inspector panel is displayed. The value of a script variable is changed, and this causes the choice in the menu to change.

item.content:encoded: It is neat that you can export variables from your scripts and toggle them in the Godot editor while the game is running to quickly see what changing the state would do at any given moment. It's something I haven't really played with too much before, but I find it useful now that I am dipping my toes in that üåäwater. #FediverseJam #GodotEngine

item.title: I wish my laundry app didn't require knowing my location...
item.description: I wish my laundry app didn't require knowing my location to connect to the laundry machine. Why is that important? The machine won't start if no one's at it pressing the "start" button. Are they afraid someone is going to remotely give out free washes to a random person who is at the machine? They already require that Bluetooth is enabled. They could be using that to detect what machines are nearest to me, but they still require location services.
item.content:encoded: I wish my laundry app didn't require knowing my location to connect to the laundry machine. Why is that important? The machine won't start if no one's at it pressing the "start" button. Are they afraid someone is going to remotely give out free washes to a random person who is at the machine? They already require that Bluetooth is enabled. They could be using that to detect what machines are nearest to me, but they still require location services.

item.title: Hi, I'm Emma üëãI üíºwork as a full-stack dotnet developer,...
item.description:
Hi, I'm Emma üëã

I üíºwork as a full-stack dotnet developer, and I am an üå†aspiring üïπÔ∏ègamedev. I ‚ù§Ô∏èlove to participate in game jams. I enjoy üßü‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èhorror media, and all things ghoulish, creepy or otherwise unsettling. In my free time, I work on FreeTubeCordova (an android fork of FreeTube, the üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏èprivacy focused YT app). I am a Satanist and a witch, but don't worry, I don't üßõ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èbite and am always üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èlooking for friends (especially if you want to üë•group up for a game jam). #introductions
item.content:encoded:

item.title: It works in dev. Why doesn't it work in prod?
item.description: What is that? That little üòàinsidious thing that happens when you üöÄdeploy code that you've solidly vetted into your production environment. Where does that come from?
item.content:encoded:
I enjoy a solid code üìÑreview, but I am not always working with other ü´Çpeople when I code. Either way, I üò£dislike the feeling of accidentally introducing üêõbugs with my code. I've done it before, and I am the type of person to wake up in a üßäcold sweat in the middle of the üåînight wondering why that page just doesn't quite scroll to the top in the right way.

It is even more üëªsoul crushing when that issue doesn't even happen until the code has gone through a üîÅcontinuous integration workflow and ended up in some data center somewhere; oh, and also, all of the source maps are gone. This isn't even considering that you might be working on something highly üëÅvisible that you wouldn't really want to be working on in production while there are people actively interacting with it.

Why doesn't it work?

Maybe, it is a bad ‚öôconfig, or maybe, the thing you designed is fundamentally incompatible with the thing you are hosting it on, or maybe, it is just a bad ‚öôconfig. It is really hard to tellü§î. Is it even üöÄdeploying? Hold on, let me read the logs.

Oh, I think I fixed it!

Oh, wait, no. It was just cached from before it broke.

Is this just a part of being human?

Am I doomed to fail? Is acceptance of my humanity the only thing that will relieve me from my üò£suffering? I don't know. I can't say for sure, but I do know that, as a üë©human, I am bound to make ‚ùåmistakes. I am getting better at not ruminating on the past, but my progress isn't a straight üìàline. Growth is all about making mistakes. You can't learn how to do something unless you try. You can't know if something works in production unless you put it in production.

So, go ahead! Press that üöÄdeploy button!

Unless, that is a bad idea for you; idk your lifeü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

item.title: Writing the same trivial site in üë©‚ÄçüöÄAstro & ‚ö°Qwik
item.description: I wrote this whole trivial site with two very similar but different stacks.
item.content:encoded:
"Now, wait a minute . . ." you might be saying to yourself,
"Is it really fair to compare a framework that is production ready with one that is not production ready?"

ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èProbably not

However, I am not going to let that stop me from having a little fun. I created two repos about a month ago: AstroVueStaticSite and QwikStaticSite. They are two different versions of my website. In most ways, they are indistinguishable, but they aren't exactly the same.

Attempting to reach feature parity

Qwik isn't even v1 yet, but it does have a lot of üîîbells and üé∑whistles that make it more appealing (to me) over Astro. Despite Qwik's lack of a hydration step, it generates MPAs with client side navigation that takes over after the first load, and this is because it introduces this entirely new concept of resumability. If you haven't üëÇheard of it, it makes üíßhydration feel archaic. It makes me ü§îwonder why a lot of JavaScript meta-frameworks server-side render only to dispose of the current state and üí¶rehydrate on the client. It just seems üóëwasteful. On the other hand, resumuability is quite conservative with its waste; the browser picks up with the framework right where the server left off. ü•§Rehydration isn't necessary because the state is serialized into the HTML; there is no need to regenerate the shadow DOM because the real DOM is already the truth.

That all being said, Astro is production ready, and while it doesn't do everything that Qwik does out of the boxüì¶, it knows its scope. It solves the problem of generating static sites. It doesn't attempt to change anything about the paradigms of how JavaScript frameworks work, and in fact, it works with existing frontend UI frameworks such as Vue and Svelte. It introduces the idea of üèùislands, but it doesn't fundementally change hydration; it only makes it an opt-in process on a component level.

How do we get client side navigation in Astro?

There is this JavaScript library known as @hotwire/turbo. It isn't anything üéÅnew, but dang it, it handles client side navigation in a way which easily snaps into any existing MPA.

For instance, if you want to keep your layout on the page while the page content is the only thing that needs to change, all you need to do is add the following code to your `layout.astro` file:

javascript: 
      
import * as turbo from '@hotwire/turbo'
turbo.start()
// everything below this is just to handle window scrolling
const beforeRender = () => {
  document.removeEventListener('turbo:before-render', beforeRender)
  // scrolls the page to the top
  window.scrollTo(0, 0)
}
document.addEventListener('turbo:load', () => {
  document.addEventListener('turbo:before-render', beforeRender)
})

html: 
      
<!-- 
  data-turbo-action="advance"
  - makes the back button work
-->
<turbo-frame id="main-content" data-turbo-action="advance" >
  <!-- Surround the things that you want to change on your page with this element -->
  <slot/>
</turbo-frame>

Everything outside this frame will not change on page navigation.

Of course, there are other more complicated ways to use this powerful library, but I just wanted to demonstrate a very specific example. If you are interested in learning more about turbo-frames, this documentation was very helpful for me. There is also a quite informational video on how to do something similar to this with both this library and the Shared Element Transistion API available in Chrome.

More similar than you might think

Both use vite, both use directory based routing with square brackets for url parameters, both use JSX-like syntax to some extent, and because of this, a lot of things were very "‚úÇcopy and üìãpaste."

I used Vue along with Astro in order to achieve some of the client-side functionality I achieved with Qwik components, but I also used it because I ‚ù§like Vue. At the end of the day, this is the biggest difference between the repos: Vue vs JSX syntax.

Honestly, my biggest gripe about Qwik so far is it's insistence on being "React-like." As someone who is not a ‚öõReact developer, for üéâfun or for üí∂profit, I feel like there are things I like about this syntax, but there are also things I find unintuitive about it such as `useWatch$` or I ü§îguess now `useTask$` in the latest development version of Qwik.

That is another thing. I would not recommend using Qwik at this point in time because it is not ready for production. If you start building a Qwik app at this point it time, you will have to make many revisions before a production ready version is released, and as such, I would highly recommend anyone interested in using Qwik to build an app, at this point in time, to seriously consider Astro + their favourite frontend framework instead. It is more stable. It is production ready now. It (probably) won't have major breaking changes before you release.

That all being said. I think Qwik is üî•dank af, and resumability is the future of web frameworks.
